citeinfo.title: Coastal wetland vegetation and elevation data characterizing a Sudden Vegetation Dieback event in San Bernard National Wildlife Refuge in 2019
Extreme Precipitation and Flooding Contribute to Sudden Vegetation Dieback in a Coastal Salt Marsh

descript.abstract: Climatic extremes are becoming more frequent with climate change and have the potential to cause major ecological shifts and ecosystem collapse. Along the northern Gulf of Mexico, a coastal wetland in the San Bernard National Wildlife Refuge in Texas suffered significant and acute vegetation dieback following Hurricane Harvey in 2017. We identified plant zonal boundaries along an elevation gradient with drought-tolerant plant species, including succulents and graminoids, at higher elevations and flood-tolerant species, including Spartina alterniflora, at lower elevations. We measured mean canopy height for each species. Soil surface elevation was measured using Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) methods.
descript.purpose: The objective of this research was to quantify the relationship between extreme abiotic conditions with large-scale plant mortality in coastal wetlands to provide an indicator of ecosystem vulnerability to climate extremes.

procstep.procdesc:
Study Location and Experimental Design
The study was conducted in September/October 2019 in the San Bernard National Wildlife Refuge (NWR), which is located along the northern Gulf of Mexico, in the mid-coast region of Texas. San Bernard NWR extends across 22,000 hectares, containing habitats ranging from bottomland forests along the Brazos River and San Bernard River seaward to tidal fresh marshes and salt marshes bordering the Gulf of Mexico. This study focused on the salt marsh habitat, where large areas of Spartina alterniflora dieback were observed following Hurricane Harvey in 2017. In addition to S. alterniflora dieback, the salt marshes contained large areas of surviving healthy S. alterniflora, as well as other graminoid plants, including Distichlis spicata, and several succulent plant species, including Batis maritima, Lycium carolinianum, Monanthochloe littoralis, Borrichia frutescens, and Salicornia depressa. Eight study sites with prominent occurrence of S. alterniflora dieback were selected within the salt marsh habitat. Within each site, cover categories were defined to characterize dominant plant communities, S. alterniflora dieback zones, and areas of open water. Common to all sites, four cover categories were defined, which included “Open Water”, “Spartina Dieback”, “Spartina” and “Distichlis and Succulents”. Open water was defined as an area of open water at least 4 meters squared. The Spartina Dieback cover category was devoid of live vegetation, containing standing dead S. alterniflora, or “stubble”, which is a term used in the salt marsh dieback literature. The Spartina category contained healthy live S. alterniflora, and the “Distichlis and Succulents” category was heterogeneous, characterized by distinct patches of D. spicata monocultures, a mixture of D. spicata and multiple succulent species, and succulent-only species. Except for the “Distichlis and Succulents” category, five plots were established for data collection within each cover category. Because the “Distichlis and Succulents” category was not homogenous, five plots were established in each distinct patch, for a total of 15 plots per site for this cover category. In total, 225 plots were established among the eight sites. Plot location was determined by walking in the direction of a randomly-selected azimuth for at least 15 meters and until the first encounter of a patch within the target cover category. This ensured that all plots within each cover category were at least 15 meters apart.

Field Data Collection
Within each 0.25 square meter plot (i.e. 0.5 meter x 0.5 meter), vegetation canopy cover, canopy height, and surface elevation were measured. Canopy cover for each species was visually estimated along a continuous scale from 0-100 percent cover (i.e. cover categories were not used), and visual estimation was performed by the same two researchers (C. Stagg and M. Osland) for consistency across all plots. Mean canopy height was visually estimated for each species and did not account for the relative cover of bare ground. Bare ground was calculated as the difference between 100 percent and the sum of percent cover of all species within the plot. Soil surface elevation was measured using Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) surveying (Gao et al., 2005) with a Trimble R10 GNSS System (Trimble Navigation Limited, USA; Chen et al., 2011) in combination with a real-time Continuously Operating Reference Station (CORS) network developed by the Texas Department of Transportation, which provides surface elevation data rectified to the North American Vertical Datum of 1988 (NAVD 88). Upon initiation and completion of the survey, the GNSS equipment was calibrated with established elevation monuments, and data was post-processed using Trimble Business Center 2.5 software (Trimble Navigation Limited, USA). GNSS elevation data points were derived from 3-minute observations in each plot for a total of 225 3-minute elevation data points.
